Description.val:
Underwater Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) program supplies EOD and Maritime Expeditionary forces with the necessary allowance outfitting, and diving and diving-related equipment aligned to fulfill assigned missions that includes Expeditionary Mine Countermeasures (ExMCM), and other Maritime Expeditionary missions. Most equipment must have inherently low acoustic and magnetic signatures to support maritime operations in the vicinity of influence fired ordnance. This funding supports outfitting the Navy's only comprehensive capability in the fleet that can conduct full spectrum detect-to-engage ExMCM missions. Specifically, the Underwater Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) program supports EOD Groups, Units, Platoons, and Detachments worldwide as well as Mobile Diving and Salvage Units (MDSUs) across the globe.

The nature of the missions assigned to EOD and MCM forces under OPNAVINST 3501.97H, Required Operational Capabilities & Projected Operational Environments (ROC/POE), require an aggregated set of systems and equipment to perform the wide range of mine countermeasures, underwater detection, location, investigation, force protection, exploitation, and neutralization tasks that comprise the mission set. The requirements for the procurement of each of these system suites are articulated in OPNAV approved requirements documents in accordance with DoD Directive 5000.2, SECNAVINST 5000.2E, and the JCIDS process as defined by CJSCINST 3170.01 and defined by the JROC approved ExMCM ICD.

Beginning in FY 21 and continuing across the FYDP, funding previously included in BLI 0977 for procurement of Expeditionary MCM Unmanned Undersea Vehicles (UUVs) is now included in the Small And Medium Class UUV BLI 1611.

Justification.val:
FY 2021 funding is required to continue procurement and fielding of Underwater EOD program systems and equipment to outfit Expeditionary MCM Companies, EOD and Mobile Salvage units with advanced sensors and hardware required to accomplish their OPNAV approved Required Operational Capability and Projected Operational Environments. This equipment will allow warfighters to detect, locate, neutralize and render safe unexploded ordnance including improvised explosive devices.

Additionally, FY 2021 funding is required to procure systems for Expeditionary MCM forces to include diving systems designed and first produced over 40 years ago that are obsolete. Additionally, this line enables production engineering and integrated logistics support needed for all Expeditionary MCM Companies, EOD Units, and Expeditionary Salvage units. These systems provide the only expeditionary mine interdiction capability in the US Navy. If not properly outfitted, these EOD forces, organized as Expeditionary MCM Companies will not be able to detect, locate, neutralize, and render safe underwater ordnance, sea mines, and other explosive hazards, which will significantly degrade Fleet maneuver against near peer adversaries. Specifically, this procures the next generation of Underwater Breathing Apparatus (Multi Mission UBA - MMUBA), significantly increasing EOD diver capability and system reliability to neutralize, destroy, or recover undersea mines. Remotely Operated Vehicles (ROV) will be procured to provide standoff EOD Response capabilities for mine/unexploded ordnance (UXO) target prosecution beyond depths of the diver or in situations where exposure is unnecessary.

Name.@footnote: CE 1.1.1 MIW-VIP: MIW-VIP measures magnetic and acoustic signatures of equipment that will be exposed to influence (magnetic and acoustic) ordnance in combat.  This effort utilizes existing ranges and portable ranges (Forward Area Combined Degaussing and Acoustic Range (FACDAR)). Measurements are taken in both homeport areas and deployment areas to assess susceptibility of equipment to prioritized and emerging near peer competitor threat mines.  Efforts across the FYDP include ranging newly fielded Expeditionary MCM RHIBS, newly fielded equipment (OPNAV approved Expeditionary MCM Table of Allowance items such as the Multi Mission Underwater Breating Apparatus and Diver Handheld Sonar (STRIDENT)) and unmanned systems (i.e. MK 18 UUVs, MK18 Incremental Upgrade Kits, and underwater ROVs).   FY2021 efforts will focus on ranging system components and sub-systems to determine specific signature characteristics that will enable the development of credible and effective tactics and procedures to ensure survivability of these systems in various operation conditions, in addition to informing design of future systems to reduce overall signature to influence fired underwater enemy ordnance.

CE 2.1.1 ExMCM EOD Response Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV): Provides for procurement funding for OPNAV approved fleet outfitting of the MK19 Mod 2 Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV). This capability will significantly reduce operational risk to EOD divers, as this underwater ROV will be used in operational scenarios where risk to the EOD diver is too great or when utilization of an EOD diver is unnecessary.
Name.val: 2.1.1) ExMCM EOD Response Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV)

Name.@footnote: CE 2.1.2 UNDERWATER DIVER INTEGRATION SYSTEMS (e.g. STRIDENT): Provides for the procurement of a specialized EOD Diver underwater handheld sonar that is developed to operate in an influence fired ordnance environment. Unit cost of individual retrofit kits may vary based on number and type of technology included in the kit.

CE 2.1.3 ADVANCED FIRING SYSTEMS: Provides for the procurement of improved underwater acoustic transmitters and receivers to provide safe stand-off command detonation capabilities to Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD ) divers. The improved firing systems will address the current capability shortfalls of the legacy MK 12 Acoustic Firing System, which has been removed from service due to safety issues.
CE 2.1.4 INFLUENCE SIGNATURE REDUCTION: Funding procures reduction of acoustic, magnetic and seismic signatures for equipment used in a suspected minefield.

CE 2.1.6 MMUBA EQUIPMENT: These resources will procure the Multi-Mission Underwater Breathing Apparatus, which replaces the aging MK-16 UBA.  This procurement will substantially improve a diver's ability to quickly and effectively counter enemy influence ordnance, which will decrease the detect to engage timeline and open sea lanes more quickly to Fleet maneuver and commercial shipping.

CE 3.1.1. UNDERWATER (UW) INTEGRATED SYSTEM INTERFACE: Outfitting of the upgrade of COIN (Common Operator Interface, Navy, a graphical user interface) to interoperate with the MK 18 Family of Systems and the advanced sensors. COIN upgrades resourced will ensure interoperability with legacy MCM assets and that the fielding of the advanced sensors will meet interoperability performance requirements.

Name.val: UQ036 - DIVER SAFETY LIFE SUPPORT EQUIPMENT

Name.@footnote: CE 4.1.1 DIVER SAFETY LIFE SUPPORT EQUIPMENT: Provides for the procurement of a family of systems based on MOTS and mature technologies to provide safer tools and life support systems for EOD UMCM and MDSU operations. Based on family of systems concept, unit cost of individual systems and sub-systems will vary based on number and type of technology included.

CE 5.1.1 MMS FIELDING AND INVESTMENT:  Funding procures investment items required to maintain the MK7 Marine Mammal System and equipment required in the procurement, training, and production of new MK 7 MMS detachments in support of Maritime Homeland Defense and OPLAN MCM requirements.  These systems are produced to replace MMS systems that have naturally aged beyond their operationally effective lifespans.  Funding supports material and infrastructure items for the training of new MMS systems, investment level veterinary equipment (IAW SECNAVINST 3900.41), and outfitting of tools/equipment for all Fleet MMS in accordance with CNO approved allowance list. The MK 7 MMS remains the only operational buried mine hunting capability in the US Navy.

CE 6.1.1 MK 18 MOD 2 RETROFIT KITS INCREMENT:(Autonomy and Automated Target Recognition): Provides for procurement of UUV MK 18 Mod 2 retrofit kits, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including GFM deployments of Expeditionary MCM Companies ISO C5F and C7F.  These retrofit kits add capability that improves reliability, autonomous features, and automated target recognition capabilities.  This upgrade kit reduces the detect to engage timeline for Expeditionary MCM Companies to enable Fleet Maneuver against near peer adversaries.

CE 6.1.2 MK18 MOD2 UUV OCO RESET: Reset funding is for replacement of UUVs lost during fleet operations in support of C5F missions. OCO resources will replace and restore deployed systems to full operational readiness to meet C5F mission needs.

CE 6.1.3 MK18 MOD2 RETROFIT KITS (SSAM) (0204224N): Provides for procurement of UUV MK 18 Mod 2 Advanced sensor retrofit kits, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including GFM deployments of Expeditionary MCM Companies ISO C5F and C7F.  These retrofit kits add advanced sensor capability to the MK18 Mod 2 which increases area coverage rate and resolution of side scan sonar images of the sea floor which decreases the detect to engage timeline for Expeditionary MCM companies to enable rapid fleet maneuver.

CE 6.1.4 MK18 MOD 2 RETROFIT KITS (ATLAS FORWARD LOOK SONAR) (0204224N): Provides for procurement of UUV MK 18 Mod 2 retrofit kits, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including GFM deployments of Expeditionary MCM Companies ISO C5F and C7F. These retrofit kits add advanced sensor capability to the MK 18 Mod 2 system, and specifically the ability to detect sea mines and other hazards in the volume of water (vice the sea floor).
Name.val: 6.1.4) MK18 MOD 2 RETROFIT KITS (ATLAS FORWARD LOOK SONAR) (0204224N)

Name.@footnote: CE 6.1.5 MK 18 MOD 2 UUV (0204224N): Provides for procurement of UUV MK 18 Mod 2 vehicles, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including GFM deployments of Expeditionary MCM Companies ISO C5F and C7F.  These UUVs are a critical component of the Expeditionary MCM detect to engage sequence for undersea mines and the inventory of these UUVs in doubling in conjunction with the growth of Expeditionary MCM Companies from 8 to 16 over the FYDP.  Unit price increase by 4.8% due to price increases for critical system component parts (i.e. inertial navigation system, side scan sonar).

CE 6.1.6 MK 18 MOD 1 UMCM UUV INCREMENTAL (CIP) Retrofit Kit (0204224N): Unit cost of individual retrofit kits may vary based on the number and type of technologies included and systems being upgraded and are identified as incremental Block Upgrades (e.g., current increment Block C retrofit kit is an upgrade in capability for the Mk 18 Mod 1 UUV system). These retrofit kits address more than one upgrade and address different functional area, i.e. enhanced navigation, system autonomy, improved post mission analysis, etc. Accordingly the number of retrofit kits may exceed number of systems/vehicles fielded
Name.val: 6.1.6) MK 18 MOD 1 UMCM UUV INCREMENTAL (CIP) Retrofit Kit (0204224N)

Name.@footnote: CE 7.1 PRODUCTION ENGINEERING: Funding supports the production of, EOD Response ROVs, Multi Mission Underwater Breathing Apparatus, Diver Handheld Sonar, and other EOD equipment requiring additional production support to include production contract award, first article tests, and factory acceptance tests. This line enables the rapid and seamless transition from development to production, which is critical to the schedule for delivery of these Expeditionary MCM equipment items. The Navy's Expeditionary MCM Capacity is growing to 16 companies over the course of the FYDP which requires additional and accelerated production of equipment by industry and government partners.

CE 8.1 PRODUCT IMPROVEMENT: Provides for engineering services to improve fielded EOD Diver-based and unmanned systems to improve Human Systems Integration (HSI)/Logistics domains insert technology refresh and/or decrease costs.

CE 9.1 INITIAL TRAINING: Funding provides resources needed due to the increase in training requirements due to expanded employment of fleet systems and the fielding of new systems and incremental upgrades to existing systems. This line funds the development of initial training courses, computer based training, training manuals, and the development of NTSPs for EOD Response ROVs, Multi Mission Underwater Breathing Apparatus, Diver Handheld Sonar, and Advanced Firing Systems. This training is required based on execution of acquisition programs, ECPs and product improvements

Remarks.val:
[Hardware/Recurring] [Hardware/Recurring] ExMCM Outfitting: This funding resources the procurement of Expeditionary systems and support equipment. Procurement of this equipment will allow the ExMCM forces to be deployed globally and employed from a wide variety of shipboard platforms at sea as well as small craft in performing EOD and EXMCM missions in support of global requirements. The various ExMCM outfitting kits comprise the ancillary and support equipment necessary to outfit an ExMCM Company with equipment based on approved Tables of Allowances (TOAs) and are procured from a variety of OEMs and sources.

UUV funding previous provided under Cost Elements 1.1.1. - 1.1.6 has been re-programmed to newly established BLI 1611 Small and Medium Class UUVs.

Name.@footnote: CE 1.1.1 MK18 MOD 1 UUV (0207404N): Provides for procurement of UUV MK18 Mod 1 vehicles, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including rotational deployments to the Fifth Fleet and Seventh Fleet areas of responsibility.

CE 1.1.2 EXPEDITIONARY MCM (ExMCM) MK 18 MOD 2 UUV: Provides for procurement of UUV MK 18 Mod 2 vehicles, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including GFM deployments of Expeditionary MCM Companies ISO C5F and C7F.  These UUVs are a critical component of the Expeditionary MCM detect to engage sequence for undersea mines and the inventory of these UUVs in doubling in conjunction with the growth of Expeditionary MCM Companies from 8 to 16 over the FYDP.

CE 1.1.3 MK18 MOD 1 UMCM UUV INCREMENTAL (CIP) RETROFIT KITS (0207404N): Unit cost of individual retrofit kits may vary based on the number and type of technologies included and systems being upgraded and are identified as incremental Block Upgrades (e.g., current increment Block C retrofit kit is an upgrade in capability for the MK18 MOD 1 UUV System) these retrofit kits address more than one upgrade and address different functional area, i.e. enhanced navigation, system autonomy, improved post mission analysis, etc.  Accordingly the number of retrofit kits may vary in the number of systems/vehicles fielded.
Name.val: 1.1.3) MK18 MOD 1 UMCM UUV INCREMENTAL (CIP) RETROFIT KIT (0207404N)

Name.@footnote: CE 1.1.4 MK18 MOD 2 RETROFIT KITS SYNTHETIC APERTURE SONAR (SSAM) (0207404N): Provides for procurement of UUV MK 18 Mod 2 Advanced sensor retrofit kits, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including GFM deployments of Expeditionary MCM Companies ISO C5F and C7F.  These retrofit kits add advanced sensor capability to the MK18 Mod 2 which increases area coverage rate and resolution of side scan sonar images of the sea floor which decreases the detect to engage timeline for Expeditionary MCM companies to enable rapid fleet maneuver.

CE 1.1.5 MK18 MOD 2 RETROFIT KITS (ATLAS) (0207404N): Provides for procurement of UUV MK 18 Mod 2 retrofit kits, which will be employed in operational missions in Shallow Water (SW) and Very Shallow Water (VSW) environments including GFM deployments of Expeditionary MCM Companies ISO C5F and C7F. These retrofit kits add advanced sensor capability to the MK 18 Mod 2 system, and specifically the ability to detect sea mines and other hazards in the volume of water (vice the sea floor).

CE 1.1.6 ExMCM AUXILIARY, SUPPORT, MAINTENANCE, and MISSION SUPPORT EQUIPMENT KITS: The ExMCM Aux Kits includes equipment required for ExMCM deployment, pre-mission planning and post mission analysis. In addition, new procurement auxiliary kits will need to be procured to support enhancements to legacy fleet systems through engineering changes, system upgrades and obsolescence of legacy auxiliary kits. Items include those required to deploy the ExMCM equipment such as transport carts, transport cases, test equipment, pre-mission planning equipment not covered in the support or maintenance kits The ExMCM Support Kit comprises GETACs, PMA stations, cross-domain modules, and other support items that comprise a portion of the ExMCM system outfitting. The Maintenance Kit comprises special tool kits, calibration equipment, fly away maintenance modules, and other maintenance items. Unit cost of individual kits may vary based on number and type of technology included in each kit.

CE 1.1.7 ExMCM DIVER SENSOR/NAVIGATION SYSTEMS: Provides for the procurement of a specialized EOD Diver underwater handheld sonar that is developed to operate in an influence fired ordnance environment. Unit cost of individual retrofit kits may vary based on number and type of technology included in the kit.

CE 1.1.8 ExMCM EOD RESPONSE REMOTELY OPERATED VEHICLE (ROV): Procurement of EOD Response vehicles and associated sub-systems to leverage advancements in robotic manipulators, target recognition software, user interface, and explosive recognition and neutralization that have been achieved in land robots and which can now be integrated into undersea remotely operated vehicles. These EOD response systems will enable more rapid reacquisition, identification and neutralization of mine like targets found by other search assets.
Name.val: 1.1.8) ExMCM EOD RESPONSE REMOTELY OPERATED VEHICLE (ROV)

Name.@footnote: CE 1.1.9 ExMCM TOA EQUIPMENT: Procurement of EXMCM Company Table of Allowance (TOA) equipment for the sixteen ExMCM companies supporting global operations.

CE 1.1.10 ExMCM OPEN WATER TRANSPORT SYSTEM/SHIPBOARD CHARGING CONTAINER OWTS/SCC: Supports initial fielding of hardware of the Open Water Transport equipment and shipboard charging containers. Anticipated delivery schedule 2 per month.
Name.val: 1.1.10) ExMCM OPEN WATER TRANSPORT SYSTEM/SHIPBOARD CHARGING CONTAINER OWTS/SCC

Name.@footnote: CE 1.1.11 ExMCM PROCUREMENT (C6F): Funding will procure critical ExMCM equipment needed to outfit deploying CTF 68 forces in support of ongoing USN operations in USSIXTHFLT AoR.

CE 1.1.12 ExMCM DIVER EQUIPMENT: These resources will procure the Multi-Mission Underwater Breathing Apparatus, which replaces the obsolete MK-16 UBA. This procurement will substantially improve a diver's ability to quickly and effectively counter enemy influence ordnance, which will decrease the detect to engage timeline and open sea lanes more quickly to Fleet maneuver and commercial shipping.

Remarks.val: [Hardware/Recurring] MK 18 UUV outfitting in support of Naval Special Operation Forces.

Name.@footnote: CE 1.1.1 MK18 MOD 1 UUV: Baseline funding provides for the replacement procurement of (4) MK18 MOD1 UUV in support of contingency Naval Special Warfare missions. The MK18 UUV systems have been identified as a Navy service-common systems and beginning in FY18 are funded using Department of the Navy resources. Previous MK18 UUV systems were procured by Special Operations Command (SOCOM) funding. Unit cost increase in FY21 allows for the procurement of a MK18 MOD1 UUV System.  FY20 OPN funds insufficient to procure a full MK18 MOD1 UUV System. Technical Adjustment in FY21 and outyears adds OPN funds to allow for procurement of one system per year.
